tossups.question: In non-Abelian theories, the Lagrangian contains a term equal to minus one divided by the square of this value times the trace of the field tensor. In one instance, this dimensionless quantity can be converted into one with a value of 220 MeV in a process called "dimensional transmutation." For a generic scattering process, the matrix element equals the product of each vertex's value of this quantity times the propagator. A field theory is referred to as "scale invariant" when this quantity is independent of the energy scale. Taking the derivative of this value with respect to the logarithm of the energy scale gives the beta function, which describes the “running” of this value. If this value decreases as distance decreases and energy increases, the result is called asymptotic freedom. For 10 points, name this value denoted g, which gives the strength of an interaction in a quantum field theory.

On Christmas Eve, this person’s mom calls him the “man of the house”, to which he says “I am not a man. I am a boy.” This student at the Brimmer school cons his friend Roger Crosby out of several wheelbarrows full of toy soldiers, but is forced to return them. This man sits mixing a “black pile” of earth and a “white pile” of lime at Char-de-sa farm in a scene describing his uncle’s death of Hodgkin’s disease. This character’s daughter rises “like the sun” “in her flame-flamingo infants’ wear” in a work in which he concludes “Cured, I am frizzled, stale and small.” He recounts his encounter with a “czar” of “Murder Incorporated” in a poem describing his time in jail for not registering for the draft. 91 Revere Street was the address of, for 10 points, what speaker of “Home After Three Months Away” and “Memories of West Street and Lepke”, two poems from Life Studies?
tossups.answer: Robert Lowell [accept either underlined answer , or “Bob”]

tossups.question: A teenage Freddie Hubbard started his career playing with this artist and his two brothers, who formed a group called The [this man's last name] Brothers Plus Five Others. This artist often divided his solos into three sections: first playing only single-note lines, then only parallel octaves, then finally full block chords. One of his jazz standards opens with 4 repetitions of the quarter-note bass line "low G-D-C-high G." This artist covered the theme song from the movie Cool Hand Luke in the title track of his album Down Here on the Ground. This artist produced three collaborative albums with the organist Jimmy Smith. The tracks "Unit 7" and "Four on Six" were popularized in part by an album this artist recorded with the Wynton Kelly trio. For 10 points, name this jazz guitarist who used his thumb as a pick and also made Smokin' at the Half Note and albums whose titles are puns on a cardinal direction.

In this novel, a retired astronaut tells the protagonist that "Returning from the moon was not the same as going, played backwards.” Another character in this novel is only ever heard through a grate in a monastery. That character, Mr. Calkins, publishes a newspaper with wrong dates as well as the protagonist's poetry collection Brass Orchids. In this novel, Bobby Richards is pushed down an elevator shaft by his sister June after he threatens to tell their parents that she had sex. The black man who may have raped June, George Harrison, becomes identified with the second moon in this novel. This novel’s protagonist wears only one shoe, and along with his lovers Lanya and Denny, leads a gang called the Scorpions whose members disguise themselves with holograms of mythical beasts. For 10 points, name this novel about The Kid's time in the ruined city of Bellona, the masterpiece of Samuel Delany.

This man’s interactions with Sylvain Maréchal secured him a post in the Food Administration. This man’s followers often chanted his song “Dying of Hunger, Dying of Cold.” The first line of his autobiography, “I was born in the mud,” refers to his background as a ditch digger from Picardy. He was aided by supporters Augustin Darthe and Philippe Buonarroti, who formed a “new” group named for this man after his death. This leader of the Society of the Pantheon praised the September Massacres for targeting “bloodsuckers”, but wrote that a more final event must occur. That event led to his death at the Vendome under the government of Paul Barras, whose rule he tried to undermine. For 10 points, name this proto-socialist who tried to overthrow the Directory by forming the Conspiracy of the Equals, and who took his moniker from an ancient Roman tribune.

This artist’s autobiography describes spending a whole month gazing at a vegetable, trying to confront its spirit. A lifelong fondness for the foxglove plant inspired this artist’s painting Digitalis in the Night, and her novel Digitalis in Central Park. Nightmares about eating pasta produced in a U.S. factory inspired this artist to use macaroni in many works. This artist’s aversion to sex led her to create a sculpture of a boat studded with hundreds of penises. At the 1966 Venice Biennale, this artist placed mirrored spheres across the exhibition lawn. This artist started a “nude fashion” company and often collaborated with Louis Vuitton. Suspended LEDs and large sculptures of pumpkins can be found in installations by this artist that surround the viewer with myriad reflections. For 10 points, name this creator of Infinity Mirror Rooms, a Japanese artist who often incorporates many polka-dots into her work.

In one novel, the actions of a character who has this physical feature lead the protagonist to recall that a fetid stench envelopes his body and sweat pours from that character’s armpits. That character with this feature is given a medallion with the letter “N” on it after sleeping with “Miss Brink”. That character who has this physical feature tries to kill himself by drinking methanol, leading the protagonist to eventually speak with the head of an abbey, who claims that she does not remember another character who had this trait. The protagonist’s lavish villa burns down after spying on a woman whom he suspects of having this feature, which leads him to believe that a Thai princess, Isao Iinuma, and his now-deceased best friend Kiyoaki Matsugae are reincarnations. For 10 points, identify this birthmark possessed by four people in Shigekuni Honda’s life in the Sea of Fertility tetralogy.
tossups.answer: having three moles [accept answers indicating a triangle of moles; prompt on birthmarks or just moles]

tossups.question: These events were investigated by an Inspectorate chaired by Sir John Wallace Pringle. One of these incidents named for Canoe River helped John Diefenbaker gain fame as a defense lawyer. Venustiano Carranza lost a third of his troops due to one of these incidents at the fort of Guadalajara in 1915. The first recorded example of one of these involved an invention of William Brunton. Parliamentary regulation was enacted after an event of this type near Armagh in 1889. In Nashville, the so-called “great” one of these events happened in 1918 at Dutchman’s Curve. Tsar Alexander III may have aggravated his nephritis when he rescued his family from one of these events, which resulted in Sergei Witte’s rise to prevent them. The 2004 “Queen of the Sea” disaster in Sri Lanka is an example of, for 10 points, what kind of calamity which first happened in Philadelphia when the Steam Horse exploded?
tossups.answer: train crash or train wreck or train disaster [or pretty much any equivalent involving a railway accident, such as a derailment or explosion of a locomotive]

tossups.question: This technique is used on algebraic approximants to build solutions to power flow equations in the HELM method. This process can be performed starting from a given point and proceeding along rays, a configuration known as the Mittag-Leffler star. It cannot be performed on power series which contain gaps between their nonzero terms according to the Hadamard-Ostrowski theorem; it also cannot be performed if all points on the circle of convergence for a function are singular. Doing this process along a curve with overlapping disks is possible via the monodromy theorem. Performing this technique on the regularized Riemann zeta function is done to show that the sum of the natural numbers converges to -1/12. The gamma function can be defined over the entire complex plane by using, for 10 points, what technique that extends the domain of a complex-differentiable function?
tossups.answer: analytic continuation [prompt on extension of a domain or continuation]

tossups.question: Marjorie Suchocki's book In God's Presence examines the meaning and efficacy of prayer under this system, for which she wrote the “practical guide”, God Christ Church. Joseph Bracken reconciled this system with the doctrine of the trinity. According to this system, God has a “primordial” and “consequent” pole, designating his potential and actual natures. This system rejects all violations of the laws of nature and views Jesus as the perfect exemplar of God's will. A center for studying this system was founded in Claremont, California by its leading scholar John B. Cobb. Many of its central tenets, including the relational and panentheistic nature of God, were outlined by Charles Hartshorne. This system privileges “becoming” instead of “being” in its conception of a mutable God. For 10 points, name this kind of theology, based on a similarly named philosophy of Alfred North Whitehead.
tossups.answer: Process Theology [or Process Theism; do not accept or prompt on “process philosophy”]

tossups.question: The principal theme of this work's first movement is introduced by violins glissing from low A-sharp up an octave, then glissing from C-sharp down to G-double-sharp. Prior to beginning work on this piece, its composer explored his "Holy Mary complex" with Sigmund Freud. The motive C-sharp, D, B, G begins the quasi-atonal opening viola soli in this piece, whose home key is F-sharp major. This symphony's composer scribbled “Farewell, my lyre” in its manuscript, the last page of which has “To live for you! To die for you!” scrawled on it. Deryck Cooke created a performing version of this work, whose “Purgatorio” movement references a wife’s affair with Walter Gropius. Leonard Bernstein refused to conduct anything beyond its opening Adagio, since that was the only movement its composer orchestrated before his 1911 death from endocarditis. For 10 points, what symphony, numerically, comes nine after one nicknamed “Titan”?
tossups.answer: Gustav Mahler’s Symphony No. 10 [accept Mahler’s Tenth Symphony and clear equivalents; prompt on partial answers]

tossups.question: These two nations came into conflict when soldiers from one killed a faith healer known as Liborio for leading a resistance movement that employed the comarca style of religious dance. One of these nations set up the SDIC to send secret loans to the other’s dictator, Ulises Heureaux. A conflict between these nations ended with the election of a political party that used the symbol of a tailless rooster, known as Los Coludos or the “Sharks,” and the adoption of a plan named for Francisco Peynado. Years later, one of these nations invaded the other in Operation Power Pack. Tensions between these two nations mounted after rebels refused to surrender at San Francisco de Macoris. That occurred after one of these nations used a force under Rear Admiral William Caperton to invade the other, and set up a military government under Harry Knapp. For 10 points, name these two countries, who negotiated the Hull-Trujillo Treaty.
tossups.answer: United States of America and Dominican Republic

tossups.question: According to the website of a guild named for it, this material’s rise was spurred by the invention of the styrofoam pillow. The first treatise on this material, which was written by Pamela Nottingham, discusses how to make the “Cluny” form of it. Catherine of Aragon supposedly taught residents of Bedfordshire how to make this material, which is why makers of it celebrate Catterntide. One of the two major mechanized methods of making this material evolved from passementerie (PASS-men-tree) in the 1500s, whereas the other major method is used to make ruticella and buratto forms of it. Point de Venise and Chantilly are types of this material, which can be made using a stiff straw cushion and a set of bobbins. A needle and thread to create embroidery around holes are often used to make, for 10 points, name what type of fabric with holes, and which is often seen on wedding gowns and table cloths?

Several nitrosyl groups are bound to one of these structures in both Roussin's red and black salts. DNA glyco∙sylases use these structures to recognize damaged DNA bases. A protein containing a corrinoid ring and one of these structures transfers a methyl group from methyl-tetra∙hydro∙folate to carbon monoxide in order to form acetyl-coA in the Wood-Ljungdahl pathway. A highly oxidized form of these structures is found in proteins in the HiPIP family. These structures can assume a cubane-like conformation in which up to 4 corners of the cube can bind to cysteine residues. One of these structures binds to citrate in a protein which forms isocitrate in the first step of the Krebs cycle. For 10 points, name these clusters which are found in a group of proteins in the electron transport chain called the ferredoxins and are named for the two elements which comprise them.

A story by this writer opens with the observation that “thrones wilt when they are not fed with blood” and concludes that Franz Joseph is a “powerful, but sad Demiurge.” In another of his stories, a woman named Adela uses her broom to clean birds from the attic of the narrator’s father. This author ‘s “The Night of the Great Season” is set during the “hunchback’d” thirteenth month of the calendar, and like “Tailors’ Dummies,” features his elderly clothmaking father Joseph as a central character; those stories appear in a collection that was translated and abridged to form Jonathan Safran Foer’s novel Book of Codes. This author was killed by a Nazi for wandering into the “Aryan” section of his hometown of Drohobych, which provides the setting for a collection of stories describing the cinnamon shops of the title road. For 10 points, name this Polish author of Street of Crocodiles.

Because this phenomenon is relatively weak for N-heterocyclic carbenes, A.B.P. Lever developed a namesake parameter to characterize their properties. In X-ray absorption spectroscopy, this phenomenon adds an additional peak to the L-edge spectrum. Measurements of this phenomenon are used to calculate the Tolman electronic parameter. This phenomenon drives the concerted oxidative addition of diatomic hydrogen to a metal via a "sigma complex." Cyanides and phosphines are near the top of the spectrochemical series because they strongly engage in this phenomenon. This phenomenon leads to a decrease in the stretching frequency of the C-O bond in carbon monoxide, a fact useful for characterizing metal carbonyl complexes using IR spectroscopy. For 10 points, name this phenomenon in which electrons are donated from an atomic orbital of a metal to an antibonding orbital of a ligand.

This book cites the author Levinus Lemnius to suggest that music is an “inamorato” that “capers in deceit all day long.” The author of this book lets his imagination soar like a “long-winged hawk” and travel to “ethereal orbs” and “celestial spheres” using Lucian of Samosata’s Icaromenippus and the Wandering Jews as guides. That section of this book “A Digression of the Air” is said to be the first ever treatise on climatology. The opening of this book contains a poem describing Superstiosus and Hellebor, two allegorical figures in a set of ten panels on this book’s frontispiece. The preface of this work features a poem addressed “to the reader who employs his leisure time ill.” Several “numbers”, “sections”, and “subsections” comprise the three “partitions” of this book, which are ascribed to Democritus Junior. For 10 points, name this text by Robert Burton, in which he was stricken with “black bile.”

One person present at this event reported to a journalist at the New Paper that it was caused by a scuttled arms deal with a German riflemaker, which cost over a million dollars, relying on the testimony of survivors like Ketaki Chester. In the wake of this event, a ritual known as “katto” which involves eating the bone from a human body, was performed to cleanse negative karma. The most significant person killed at this event had issued a declaration known as the “Zone of Peace” proposal at his coronation, and was the grandson of Tribhuvan. The majority of this event’s victims died in a billiard room, and despite conspiracy theories otherwise, its perpetrator was likely taking revenge for being refused permission to marry Devyani Rana. In this event’s wake, Gyanendra Shah was appointed regent. For 10 points, name this 2001 event in which the drunken Crown Prince Dipendra gunned down ten of his relatives in Kathmandu.
tossups.answer: Nepalese Royal Massacre [or Nepalese Palace Massacre; accept equivalents that indicate the killing of the “Nepalese royal family” or the “killing of King Birendra by Dipendra”, prompt on just “killing” in Nepal]

tossups.question: A historian from this country analyzed the effect of cultural trauma on the awareness of change in his theory of “sublime historical experience.” The Nazis appropriated Peter Geyl’s idea that there was a “Greater” form of this country, and that it should be united with its western neighbor. A better-known book written by a man from here analyzed eskimos in Greenland, whose singing and drumming contests he compared to modern-day lawsuits. That book coined the term “magic circle” to refer to a temporary world of activity created apart from reality, and influenced later thinkers like Roger Caillois. That thinker from this nation wrote In the Shadow of Tomorrow and The Autumn of the Middle Ages, in addition to a book subtitled as a “Study of the Play-Element in Culture.” For 10 points, name the home country of the author of Homo Ludens, Johan Huizinga.
tossups.answer: the Netherlands [or Holland or the Dutch Republic]

tossups.question: This philosopher compared and contrasted various falls, such as Satan’s nine-day fall in Paradise Lost, to Thomas De Quincey’s fall in his Confessions, to show that “verticality” is a component of a human’s “ascensional” psyche. He catalogued all instances of violence against animals in the book The Songs of Maldoror to show that Lautreamont exhibited a “phenomenology of aggression.” This philosopher distinguished between “formal,” “material,” and “dynamic” components of the human imagination in his “essay on the imagination of movement”. This philosopher’s book Air and Dreams is one of many to discuss the power of “reverie.” In his most read work, this philosopher presents a topoanalysis of a building by constructing a psychological polarity between the attic and the cellar. For 10 points, name this French philosopher who analyzed the domestic house in The Poetics of Space.

bonuses.leadin: Edwidge Danticat’s essay “Create Dangerously” claims that staging this play was incredibly popular in Haiti since it was a relatively easy way to criticize the oppressive regime. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this play centering on a death-obsessed man. The title character orders his servant Helicon to dredge the Moon from a lake as part of his quest to be as free as the Gods.
Caligula is a play by this author, who wrote The Just Assassins as kind of a counterpoint to Caligula to illustrate the theme of “revolt”.

Caligula was meant to be a dramatic treatment of this concept. Suicide as a solution to the philosophical problem of this concept is rejected in The Myth of Sisyphus, whose first three chapters are titled after it.

bonuses.leadin: When defending his choice to call ACT UP “fascists”, the movie critic Ed Koch responded, “Fascists can be concerned citizens”. For 10 points each:
answers: mayor of New York City [accept equivalents]
Bella Abzug [or Bella Savitsky Abzug; or Battling Bella]
parts: Ed Koch made those statements while he was serving in this office from 1978 to 1989. It was held from 1934 to 1945 by Fiorello LaGuardia.
Koch won the 1977 Democratic primary against Mario Cuomo and this woman, a Representative for New York’s 20th district. She co-sponsored the first federal gay rights bill, the Equality Act of 1974.

Koch’s replacement as mayor by David Dinkins was precipitated by the death of this 16-year old black boy in 1989 in the Bensonhurst area of Brooklyn, for which Joey Fama was convicted of second-degree murder.

bonuses.leadin: This woman’s partner kept leaving pieces of raw meat as a signal to others that he he’d not been seduced by this woman, until she made fun of him for being less bold than the water which splashed her thigh. For 10 points each:
answers: smashed by/against a rock [accept any equivalent indicating death by “rocks” or “stones”, etc.; prompt on squish-squish or smashed]
choking on a fishbone [accept salmon bone in lieu of fish; prompt on choking or choke]
parts: Name this daughter of Cormac mac Art, whose desire for some berries in the forest of Dubros caused her lover Diarmuid to kill the giant Searbhan.
When three hounds are sent after Grainne, the final one is killed in this manner. Jason and the Argonauts used a dove to avoid being killed in this way by the Symplegades.

On the other hand, Grainne’s dad Cormac mac Art dies in this fashion after a druid curses him for converting to Christianity. Earlier, Cormac’s lover Achtan had a dream that a wave knocked over a giant tree, which prophesied that Cormac’s son was also meant to die this way.

bonuses.leadin: This compound mixed with glycine is used to transfer products from gel electrophoresis to a nitrocellulose membrane during Western blotting. For 10 points each:
answers: Tris [accept THAM or tris(hydroxylmethyl)aminomethane; accept Trizma from people who are especially brand-loyal to Sigma-Aldrich]
parts: Name this organic, basic compound that is often used as part of buffer solutions in biochemistry, since its buffering range, at pH 7-9, is useful for many biological processes. The two main buffers for nucleic acid gel electrophoresis both contain this compound.
Tris forms the "T" in the TBE and TAE buffers. The "E" in the TBE and TAE buffers refers to this common chelating hexadentate ligand, which is commonly used as a preservative.

The compound is called "tris" because "tris" is a prefix that tells you there are 3 of a specified ligand, in this case a hydroxy∙methyl group, bonded to the central atom. What prefix is used when there are 4 equivalents of the ligand?

bonuses.leadin: Daniel Fink advanced an early form of the theory created by these two men by identifying ten points, such as “halation of highlights” and “precise treatment of reflections.” For 10 points each:
answers: David Hockney and Charles M. Falco [accept Hockney-Falco thesis; accept the names in either order]
Johannes Vermeer [or Jan Vermeer or Johan Vermeer]
parts: Name this art historian and physicist, who collaborated on a 2001 book that argued realism in western art was achieved with the aid of the camera obscura and lenses.
The Hockney-Falco thesis claims that this Dutch artist created many of his paintings, such as Allegory of Painting, with the aid of visual tools.

This thinker argued against the Hockney-Falco thesis by pointing out the realistic texture of wedding gowns and cloth in general. This academic also wrote about the “death of the heroic landscape” in Bathers, Bodies, Beauty.

bonuses.leadin: In the introduction to the novel in which these characters appear, the author writes that they are “people who merge succesfully with their habitat. In men this is called philosophy, and it is a fine thing.” For 10 points each:
answers: John Steinbeck [or John Ernst Steinbeck Jr.]
King Arthur [accept The Acts of King Arthur and His Noble Knights]
parts: Give the collective term for a group that include Jesus and Pilon, who attain peace by sleeping in a forest. The main character of this group worked as a mule-driver during WW1, and dies after falling into a gulch.
This author ended his novel Tortilla Flat with the paisanos burning down Danny’s house after he dies.
The critic Joseph Fontelrose compares Danny in Tortilla Flat to this fictional character. Steinbeck’s last book-length work of fiction is about the “acts of” this man and his "noble" companions.

bonuses.leadin: This city was designed by superimposing two squares inside a circle. It has a radial street system and an octagonal town square. For 10 points each:
answers: Filarete (“FILL”-uh-RAY-tay) [or Antonio di Pietro Averlino; or Averulino]
parts: Name this unbuilt city laid out in the book Idea for a Universal Architecture. It is considered to be the first “ideal city” of the Renaissance.
This architect symbolically incorporated numerology and the occult, as well as Biblical virtues into his design for Sforzinda. He is a possible author of the Voynich Manuscript.
This ancient architect’s De Architectura inspired Filarete to create Sforzinda. His name is attached to an “ideal man”, who has “perfect” geometric proportions.

bonuses.leadin: The contributions of single-parent households, "private transfers", and "public transfers" to this phenomenon were laid out a 1978 paper by Diane Pearce, who coined this specific phrase. For 10 points each:
parts: Identify this state of affairs often taught in intro sociology courses. This three-word hypothesis is the trend over time of the distribution of financially worse-off people to skew heavily by gender.
Pearce also blamed the faulty design of these programs for trapping some American women in poverty. A "state" of this type uses tax revenue to fund guaranteed services such as universal healthcare.
Some time after Pearce's paper, this city pushed welfare recipients into the workforce through its GAIN program. The namesake economic "miracle" that followed was largely illusory.

bonuses.leadin: The dry adiabatic form of this quantity is constant, but the moist adiabatic variety is dependent on temperature. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this quantity, which is usually symbolized gamma. It determines whether an air parcel will reach the lifting condensation level and form clouds.
The lapse rate can be determined from one of these diagrams, named for the two variables plotted on its axes. Isotherms are drawn at a 45-degree angle on these diagrams.

To the left of the temperature curve on a skew-T log-P diagram is the curve representing the change in this value with altitude. This value is the temperature to which air must be cooled to be saturated with water vapor.

bonuses.leadin: The 1577 Battle of Lubieszow began the “Golden Age” of this type of this fighting unit under the military reforms of Stephen Bathory. For 10 points each:
answers: Battle of Klushino [or Battle of Kluszyn]
parts: Name this type of heavy cavalry unit known for elaborate armor plating. This unit fought in groups called pozcet in their Polish “winged” variant.

The winged hussars had their greatest victory under Stanislaw Zolkiewski at this 1610 battle when they were outnumbered five to one by Dmitry Shuisky’s Russian force, but crushed him on his way to Smolensk.

A badass named Krzysztof “The Thunderbolt”, who was a member of this family, led a thousand Hussars to victory at the Battle of Kokenhausen in the Polish-Swedish War. Sigismund II Augustus took its member Barbara as his mistress.

bonuses.leadin: In this section, a mysterious Book of the Lion is mentioned, which does not survive. For 10 points each:
parts: Identify this section of a larger work in which the author thanks the “Lord Jesus Christ” for allowing him to translate Boethius, but seeks mercy for having written portions of the larger work that “tend toward sin”.
Chaucer’s Retraction closes this work, which is narrated in part by the prioress, the knight, and the squire.

Chaucer’s Retraction follows this longest tale, which is actually a massive prose text on the nature of forgiveness and penance. In the general prologue, the teller of this tale contrasts himself with a “shiten shepherd” that watches white sheep.

bonuses.leadin: A 30-second film reel discovered in 2011 is the only known footage of this group, whose founder believed that no camera could do them justice. For 10 points each:
answers: Le spectre de la rose [or The Specter of the Rose or The Spirit of the Rose]
parts: Name this Paris-based performing group founded by Serge Diaghilev. Its dancers and choreographers included Vaslav Nijinsky.
This man succeeded Nijinsky as the company’s principal choreographer, in which role he worked on the premieres of Manuel de Falla’s The Three-Cornered Hat and Ottorino Respighi’s The Magic Toyshop.

This 1911 ballet, which Michel Fokine choreographed to music of Carl Maria von Weber, ended with Nijinsky leaping out a window. This work was the last ballet Rudolf Nureyev and Margot Fonteyn ever danced together.

bonuses.leadin: The TRAP complex is localized to this structure. For 10 points each:
answers: phenylalanine and glycine [accept F and G]
parts: Name this protein complex, which in eukaryotes contains a central hetero∙trimer of Sec61 proteins. Proteins are targeted to this complex by the signal recognition particle.
The translocon is a protein channel located in this structure, which also contains a heat shock protein called BiP and the enzyme protein disulfide isomerase.
In contrast to the ordered structure of the translocon, nuclear pore complexes contain natively unfolded domains which are rich in these two amino acids.

bonuses.leadin: This theory of semantics assigns functions that maps a word or name’s content to a function that outputs extensions. For 10 points each:
answers: possible worlds [do not accept or prompt on worlds]
parts: Name this approach to semantics developed by David Kaplan. Robert Stalnaker created a matrix that plots various “characters” to indexicals to graph a proposition’s overall meaning as part of this approach.

In two-dimensionalism, a semantic function considers the set of all of these things to determine a semantic value. In Stalnaker’s modal semantics, necessarily true claims must be true in all of these.
This man’s concept of rigid designators found in Naming and Necessity were used to develop the earlier and less expressive “one-dimensional semantics.”

bonuses.leadin: This country’s Progressive Party under Gabriel Lisette marched under the slogan “Enough with cotton! Enough with taxes! Enough with chiefs!” which helped drive this country's independence movement. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this country which was embroiled in civil war after its general Félix Malloum and Hisséne Habré conspired to overthrow the government.
This man became the first president of Chad on its independence from France in 1960, and ruled until 1975, banning all parties other than his own PPT.
The post-Tombalbaye regime in Chad frequently clashed with Libya over this strip of land thought to be rich in uranium, which Chad wrested away after the Toyota War.

bonuses.leadin: The word alchemy comes from the Arabic word “al-kimiya”, which was the title of this man’s Book of Stones. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this 8th-century polymath whose methodical experimentation into alchemy helped pave the way for chemistry as a science. His use of a kind of proto-technobabble may have inspired the word “gibberish”.

Geber was one of the earliest to use this acid, which has the ability to dissolve gold. This “royal water” was used by George de Hevesy to conceal two Nobel prizes during the Nazi invasion of Denmark.

Rather than creating gold, many Muslim alchemists including Geber seem to have had this ultimate goal, which is the creation of artificial plants, animals, and minerals in the lab. Please give the Arabic term.

bonuses.leadin: This novel’s narrator's mother, Bugam Dasi, is a dancer who forces her two lovers to undergo a 'trial by cobra' that ends with the death of the narrator’s father. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this novel, a surreal account of the doomed love of an unnamed pen-case decorator, who narrates his darkest thoughts to his own bird-shaped shadow.
The Blind Owl was written by an author from this modern-day country. Another author from here wrote the two-part autobiographical graphic novel Persepolis.

This novelist recounts her father’s disappointment when she read The Blind Owl in the memoir Things I’ve Been Silent About. In her 2014 book The Republic of Imagination, she attacks the Common Core curriculum.

bonuses.leadin: Answer some things about Justin Trudeau’s scientific area of expertise, quantum computing. For 10 points each:
answers: decoherence [do not accept or prompt on “coherence”]
parts: A key practical problem in the field of quantum computing is avoiding this phenomenon, where a system becomes entangled with its environment, causing it to lose wave-like properties. It explains wavefunction collapse.

In this effect, which can be used to control two-level qubit states, a fluctuating EM field with frequency tuned to the energy difference between the two states can cause the system to periodically absorb and re-emit photons as it transitions between the two states.

This specific crystal defect in diamond possesses a triplet ground state, leading to luminescent properties which can be easily controlled at room temperature using electromagnetic fields, making it a promising candidate for a qubit.

bonuses.leadin: While sitting in Newgate prison for abducting an heiress, this man wrote his book A Letter from Sydney, which called for selling colonial land at artificially high prices. For 10 points each:
answers: Durham Report [or “Report on the Affairs of British North America”]
parts: Name this colonial theorist who invented the doctrine of “sufficient price”. He sought to implement his plan of “systematic colonization” as the director of the New Zealand Company.
Wakefield’s ideas inspired this 1839 report, which made recommendations about governing the colonies of Upper and Lower Canada. It was named for the title of John Lambton.
The Church of England sponsored Wakefield’s scheme to found this settlement on South Island. John Robert Godley led the expedition known as the “First Four Ships” which colonized this site.

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, answer the following about various techniques used to animate movies:
answers: Hedgehog in the Fog [or Yozhik v tuman]
parts: This tracing process invented in 1915 was used for Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs. You can see it being used in Richard Linklater’s Waking Life and those Charles Schwabb investment commercials.

Although watercolor is nearly-impossible to use in animation, this director’s recent film The Tale of Princess Kaguya used digital effects to simulate watercolor drawings. He also directed Graveyard of the Fireflies.

This 1977 short film was animated using multiple glass panels. Created by a Soviet obsessive who has spent about 40 years working on a film adaptation of The Overcoat, Yuriy Norshtein, it depicts the adventures of a woodland animal who meets an eagle-owl and a horse.
